direction.raw_text: Leaning on a railing looking down into the excavation are a group of sidewalk supervisors. The CAMERA MOVES UP to a HEAD CLOSEUP of one of them. It is Bill Cole (Melvyn Douglas), a well-dressed, intelligent, attractive looking young man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose you're wondering what all this has to do with Mr. Blandings and his Dream House? Well, I'll tell you. Jim Blandings is part of the fabric of this town. Born and raised right here, he's as typical a New Yorker as anyone you'll ever meet. At least he was. (confidentially) And if you want to know the real story, I guess I'm your boy. Cole's my name, Bill Cole. I'm Jim's lawyer and quote, best friend, unquote. Jim's one of those bright young men from Yale. Advertising business, lovely wife, two fine kids, makes almost fifteen thousand a year. Want to know why? Just look up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A billboard -- against a white background is a large ham. In large letters across the ham is printed:

dialogue.raw_text: "When you've got the whim, say 'Wham!'"... Jim Blandings wrote that slogan. Seven magic words that shine like a beacon light for the American housewife! (impressive; almost reverently) "When you've got the whim, say 'Wham!'" Jim Blandings' contribution to the American Scene.

location: A LARGE NEW YORK APARTMENT BUILDING
result.heading: EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: For fourteen years Jim and Muriel had been living in their apartment over on East Seventy-fourth Street. It was just another of those wonderful crisp September mornings and the Blandings were still asleep. Just like millions of other people in good old Manhattan -- New York City -- U.S.A.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim (Cary Grant) and Muriel (Myrna Loy) Blandings are asleep in twin beds. The room, not large to begin with, gives us the impression of being cluttered up and overcrowded because the beds, oversized chest of drawers, dressing table and chaise lounge take up an inordinate amount of space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of an alarm clock going off. Jim awakens, yawns himself into hazy consciousness, gropes about on the night table for the clock; it isn't there. He slips out of bed, and rubbing his eyes, blindly moves toward the dresser. The circuitous path, which he accomplishes with sleepy dexterity, entails going around the chaise lounge, just missing the ominously pointed edge of Muriel's dressing table, deftly stepping over the low dressing table chair and finally reaching the chest of drawers upon which is the clock. He turns off the alarm and yawningly starts back over the same path. We get the feeling that Jim makes this sleepy excursion every waking morning of his life. Back at his bed, Jim sits down, and, yawning loudly, gropes with his feet for his slippers. Before he can find them, however, he begins to doze off and slowly tilts back toward the pillow, pulling the covers over him. In a moment he is sound asleep. Muriel's arm automatically stretches out and shakes Jim into consciousness. As he painfully reawakens and starts to rise, Muriel's arm disappears. We get the impression that this, too, is a regular part of the Blandings' daily routine. Jim locates his slippers, reaches around for his bathrobe, can't find it, stumbles his way over to the closet, opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE CLOSET This is a fairly good-sized closet but it was never intended to be shared by two people, particularly not Jim and Muriel Blandings. Assuming that they had started out on even terms, it is now obviously Muriel, three-to-one. Her dresses, gowns, slips, seem to obscure his occasional pair of slacks, suit or sports coat. Her shoes neatly line the floor and the shelf above is loaded to the ceiling with her hat boxes, in an orderly but somewhat precarious state of balance. Groping blindly for a robe, Jim feels around and pulls one out. As he slips into the arms, we see it's much too small for him, obviously Muriel's. In disgust he attempts to put it back. Unable to find a hook he finally jams it in between two silk dresses which fall to the floor. As he bends down and gropes for the dresses, he discovers his robe crumpled under them on the floor. He drags the robe out and dons it, leaving the dresses where they fell. With a guilty look at Muriel he closes the closet door and starts out of the bedroom and into the narrow hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A narrow corridor extending the length of the apartment. Off it are doors leading to the bathroom, the childrens' room and the foyer. Jim shuffles down the hall. He stops at the closed bathroom door, listens, hears the shower, knocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim continues down the hall, stops at the closed door of the children's room, knocks. No sound. He opens the door and enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A small room, crowded and cluttered up with the accoutrements of adolescence. Joan, an eleven-year-old is asleep in one of the twin beds. Jim automatically pulls the covers clear off Joan's bed. She awakens, cocks an eye at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she sleepily stretches and prepares to rise, Jim exits into the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim through the foyer into the living room, on through the very small combination dining and breakfast nook and into the compact but tiny kitchen. Gussie, the colored cook, greets him heartily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gussie takes a glass of hot water, squeezes in a little lemon, stirs and hands it to Jim who gulps it down, makes a slight face and pats his stomach. Gussie hands Jim a cup of black coffee and he starts back toward the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Morning, Mr. Blandings!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a feeble attempt at a smile) Mm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gingerly balancing the cup and saucer, Jim approaches the door to the children's room. With split-second timing, he pauses as the door flies open and Joan, in her bathrobe, towel in hand, rushes out and past him down the hall. She disappears into the bathroom. Jim carefully proceeds down the hall and, as he reaches the bathroom, deftly steps to the left as the door bursts open and Betsy flies by on the way back to her bedroom. All this is done with a timing and shifting of hips of which Knute Rockne might have been proud. Jim continues down the hall, enters the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel is still asleep as Jim enters, walks over, nudges her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel awakens, sniffs the fresh coffee, smiles, sits up, takes the cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss briefly. Muriel starts to sip the coffee as Jim goes to his chest of drawers. It consists of several rows of small drawers above and large drawers below. Jim ruffles through a couple of small drawers, pulls out a suit of underwear, continues noisily and with some annoyance to look through the other drawers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches in and holds up one of Muriel's silk slips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides angrily to the closet, opens the door, reaches up for the basket and pulls it off the shelf. As he does so, all the hat boxes come tumbling down knocking the basket from his hand, the socks spilling on the floor. About to explode, he looks at Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks at her barely containing himself, and then puts the hats back in the boxes, jams them back on the shelf where they toter precariously. With bated breath he gingerly closes the closet door. Pause. Silence. He picks up a pair of socks and walks cautiously toward the hall door. Suddenly there is a rumble and crash from inside the closet. Jim exchanges a look with Muriel, is about to say something, changes his mind, exits into the hall. Muriel looks at the closet, sighs, takes another sip of coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Muriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looking for something, dear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (briefly) My socks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you look in your sock drawer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with restraint) That's where I found my underwear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. (brightly) Well, try your underwear drawer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in my underwear drawer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sipping coffee) Well, they must be somewhere. (attempt at morning cheeriness) Socks just don't get up and walk away by themselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (strained patience) Muriel, I thought the top two-and-a- half drawers were to be mine! I wish you'd tell Gussie -- MURIEL The closet! That's where they are. We put them in the closet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Socks? In the closet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there didn't seem to be any room in the drawers...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And there's so much of it in the closet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...so Gussie and I decided that from now on we'll keep them in a basket on the shelf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, thanks a lot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim, I do wish you'd make an effort to be a little less clumsy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely containing himself) I'll try, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim opens the door of the bathroom. There is a scream. He quickly closes the door, scowling with annoyance. A moment later the door opens and Joan emerges, wrapping her robe around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joan disappears into her room as Jim enters the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) Father, just one morning I wish you'd knock!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to her back as she walks away) 'Morning, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Very small with a stall shower. Jim takes off his bathrobe, yawns, gets on the scale, looks at the dial, shakes his head. He takes a deep breath, draws in his stomach, looks down, scowls, shrugs, gets off, moves to the mirror. He examines the thinness of his hair, the condition of his tongue, etc. Taking his toothbrush he looks down at the tube he is about to use, frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - the toothpaste tube. It has been squeezed in the middle, one of Blandings' pet peeves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Jim meticulously smoothes out the tube, rolls up the used portion from the bottom. Then placing a small amount on his brush, he caps the tube, and starts vigorously to brush his teeth. As he does so, he attempts with his free hand, to put the tube back in the medicine cabinet which he opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - the medicine cabinet, loaded to the hilt with medical accumulation of fourteen years of family life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Jim. As he pushes the tube into the bulging top shelf, a bottle of iodine falls out. Jim makes a desperate one-handed catch, still brushing his teeth. As he pushes the iodine into the second shelf, a small bottle of pills pops out. Jim catches it, pushes it back into the cabinet. A bottle of cough medicine falls out. He catches it, tries to put it back, finds it won't fit. He looks at the bottle, sniffs it, contemplates its value, throws it in the wastebasket. He finishes washing his mouth, admires his teeth, disrobes and steps into the shower, putting on his shower cap. He reacts, scowls, takes off the cap and turns it upside down, a full cup of water falling out. He reaches out for a towel, dries the inside of the cap, carefully puts it back on his now wet hair. Then he turns the water on and at the first warm spray Jim Blandings' life takes a sharp turn for the better. He starts to sing, a robust bathroom baritone version of "Home On The Range."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim - He stands in front of the washstand lathering his face. Over scene we hear Muriel's voice from the shower. She is singing a lusty chorus of "Home On The Range." Jim picks up his razor and turns to the mirror. He reacts with annoyance, as he discovers it is covered with steam. With weary resignation he takes a towel and starts to rub off the mirror. As he clears one section another clouds up. By the time he gets it all reasonably clear he finds that his lather needs freshening. He grimly relathers his face only to find that the mirror is again clouded up. As he turns with exasperation toward the shower we see Muriel turn off the water, reach for a towel, start to dry herself. The mirror cleared off, Jim relathers, starts to shave. During this, Muriel, having dried herself and donned her robe, comes into scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes her toothbrush and then opens the cabinet to get the paste. Jim, automatically following the mirror, has to squeeze around in a desperately contorted position as he continues shaving.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reaching for toothbrush) Excuse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Muriel. She takes the tube from the cabinet and, squeezing the tube in the middle, applies the paste to her brush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim and Muriel - Placing the tube on the washstand, Muriel closes the cabinet. Jim, still shaving, moves back to his original position as he follows the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel nods, steps back, starts to brush her teeth. They both hum "Home On The Range". Her mouth full, Muriel taps Jim on the shoulder. Without stopping his shaving, Jim moves to one side as Muriel rinses her mouth. She examines her face in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he steps back in front of the mirror, Muriel continues to look at her face in the glass, over his shoulder. She decides she needs a little skin lotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She again opens the cabinet. Jim once more follows the mirror around, nicks his face, gives up, stands glaring arms folded. Muriel takes the lotion from the cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel exits. Jim sighs, turns back to the mirror and with a few deft strokes finishes shaving. As he reaches for the water faucet, he encounters the tube of toothpaste, squeezed in the middle. Reacting with annoyance, he meticulously smoothes it out and rolls it up from the bottom. He opens the cabinet and gingerly places the tube on the top shelf. The iodine bottle pops out. He grimly catches it, studies his problem, has a solution. With his right hand he starts slowly to close the mirror door. Just before it closes, he slips the bottle into the cabinet with his left hand, quickly slamming the mirror door, trapping the bottle. He reacts masterfully at his triumph, picks up his robe and starts for the door. As he reaches it, there is the SOUND of the cabinet opening and a crash as the bottle obviously hits the washstand. As Jim winces,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BLANDINGS' BREAKFAST NOOK - DAY Narrow and small. The four Blandings are at breakfast, Jim and Muriel each reading his section of the morning paper, Betsy pasting a clipping in her notebook, Joan engrossed in a magazine of popular science. As we come in, Gussie, taking off the orange juice, is squeezing by Jim who accordingly and automatically ducks his head as she passes. Jim uncomfortably turns the newspaper to another page, folds it, reacts with pained but controlled exasperation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as she steps in front of him) Sorry.

dialogue.raw_text: Moment, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take your time. I can spare the blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't have my beard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's silly. Bill's beard is just as tough and coarse and -- JIM (irritably) I'm not interested in discussing the grain and texture of Bill Cole's hair follicles before I've had my orange juice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to carry on so. I only said, why don't you get an electric razor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I prefer the cool, clean sweep of the tempered steel as it glides smoothly -- MURIEL Stop writing advertising copy! Hurry up, dear, you'll be late for breakfast.

dialogue.raw_text: (very matter-of-factly) I did.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, father. It's necessary research.

dialogue.raw_text: (with some sarcasm) I suppose this is another of Miss Stellwagon's so-called Progressive Projects?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (using salt and handing it to Jim) Now dear, there just isn't any point in sending your children to an expensive school if you're going to undermine the teacher's authority in your own dining room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not undermining anything. I happen to be in the advertising business and keeping abreast of the times is important to me.

dialogue.raw_text: And so is your children's education.

dialogue.raw_text: (handing Joan toast) Joan, every time your father and I have a lively discussion we aren't necessarily bickering. (to Betsy; solicitously) What is it, dear, another English composition?

dialogue.raw_text: (taking toast from Joan) Miss Stellwagon has assigned each of us to take a want ad and write a human interest theme about it. (to Jim; passing toast to him) I found one typical of the disintegration of our present society.

dialogue.raw_text: (taking toast, not looking up from his paper) I wasn't aware of the fact that our society was disintegrating.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't expect you to be, father. Miss Stellwagon says that middle- class people like us are all too prone to overlook the pressures and tensions which befall the less fortunate members of our community.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with great restraint) Muriel, I know it's asking a lot, but just one morning I would like to sit down and have breakfast without social significance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim, you really might take a little more interest in your children's education.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (without looking up) You can't squeeze blood from a turnip.

dialogue.raw_text: All right. All right. I'll listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (picking up her scrapbook) It's just twenty-four words. But in simple eloquence it mirrors a minor tragedy of our times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Well?...

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak grove, apple orchard, trout stream, hay fields, four barns, seclusion, superb view, original beams, paved highway, acreage... (with emotion) Will sacrifice..."

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly, mother. What some people don't see is the whole sordid picture. A poor, honest farmer, pushed to the wall by hardship, soil erosion, mortgages, everybody gobbling, gobbling, gobbling, until finally, in desperation, he is "forced to sell," and stoops to the crass commercialism of newspaper advertising.

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) Oh, indeed... crass commercialism... advertising...

dialogue.raw_text: (with extreme control) Oh, she does?

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Stellwagon says that advertising makes people who can't afford it buy things they don't want with money they haven't got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (elaborate sarcasm) Perhaps your Miss Stellwagon is right. Perhaps I ought to get out of this "basically parasitic profession," which at the moment is paying for her very fancy tuition, those extra French lessons, her progressive summer camp and for that matter, the very braces on your teeth!

direction.raw_text: What they see -- Burrowed into the upward slope of the land is the old Hackett farmhouse. direction.raw_text: Throughout this Smith's voice remains bland and unperturbed while Jim's has the desperate, frenetic quality of a man being slowly pushed to the wall. The Special Effect concludes with the house finally and firmly at rest on the preordained $11,550. As the antagonists on both sides of the house relax, Smith reaches around in front of the house and shakes hands with Jim. It's a deal! About halfway through when the going gets tough, Jim beckons Muriel to help in the losing fight. As they now embrace, Smith and Hackett shake hands in mutual congratulation.

dialogue.raw_text: (as his hand takes pencil) Pardon me, dear. On that playroom, Simms, not too small. You know, plenty of room for ping-pong, darts, nice big poker table...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as his hand reaches for another pencil) If you don't mind, I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And off the kitchen, I'd like a little flower sink just to putter around in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And a terrace off the study, with an owning and little outdoor fireplace...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - The three are somewhat exhausted, silently looking at the plans. Simms wearily runs his hand through his hair.

direction.raw_text: THE DRAWING BOARD - SIMMS' THE DRAWING BOARD - Simms' pencil indicates as he talks.

dialogue.raw_text: (delicately) We-ll... let's just see what we have here. In the first place --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid you've got the upstairs about twice as big as the downstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all those bathrooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not, it's all those closets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim expansively puts his arm around Simms' shoulders.

direction.raw_text: . ROAD NEAR OLD HACKETT HOUSE - DAY - WINTER - (PROCESS MATTE SHOT) Old Hackett house matted to show winter sky, bare trees. In the f.g. bare ground with patches of snow. Eph Hackett is standing with one of the wreckers. In the b.g. we see the frame of the old house, firmly intact, the chimney still standing within it. There are mountains of shingles, splintered boards and other rubbish, piled about. The piles are reasonably neat and sorted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he starts out of scene:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tractors attached to chains and cables start to pull.

dialogue.raw_text: By extending this breakfast room you've eliminated the possibility of any stairs going to the second floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you can just shove those stairs in anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patiently; almost paternally) And, Mrs. Blandings, on that sewing room, the way you have it now, the chimney stack would come up right through the middle of the room, leaving you with something in the shape of a square doughnut. (tactfully) Which, of course, might be very warm in winter, but otherwise of doubtful utility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could always move the chimney somewhere else, couldn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We-ll... (rising; resigned to his fate but tactful) Look, I think I know just about what you two have in mind. Why don't I go ahead with some preliminary plans and -- JIM (hearty) You do that, Simms, but remember, we've got to hold it down to ten thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (candid) That, I can tell you right now, is impossible. Even with a considerable trimming of the things you've indicated, I don't see how we can bring it in for less than twelve or twelve-five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twelve-five! (looks at Muriel; then) Well, I guess we're not going to quibble about a few pennies one way or the other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (can't resist) No, you'll find Mr. Blandings never quibbles about pennies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And -- uh -- have you any notions about how you'd like the old place taken down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a rueful joke) Why don't we just blow on it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wry smile) There's a good local house wrecker. I'll have him contact you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. You just shoot ahead with those plans, and remember, try to keep it down to ten, ten-five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doubtfully) Well -- we'll try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's one good thing about getting that old relic down. Those original beams and everything -- this time somebody pays us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them beams is worth money. You payin' him, or he payin' you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's payin' me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitating) A thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A thousand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He squawked, but he paid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Hmm. I guess maybe I got a little somethin' comin' too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, boys, let her go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sigh) Well, so far it's cost us thirteen thousand, three hundred and twenty- nine dollars and forty-five cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But we've got the nicest vacant lot in the state of Connecticut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wearily) Something will have to give somewhere, that I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim, Muriel and Simms are going over the preliminary plans. Betsy and Joan are present, Betsy reading the Lansdale Blade and Joan reading a science book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the paper, scans it, suddenly bursts into laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The paper drops.

direction.raw_text: Muriel opens the door, admits an excited Bill Cole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim gulps. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children exit. An embarrassed pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good nights are exchanged. Muriel takes Simms out of scene toward the door. CAMERA HOLDS on Bill and Jim.

direction.raw_text: Bill looks at Jim with compassion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Jim reacts with painful resignation:

dialogue.raw_text: It's impossible. I don't see how we can cut another inch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, you heard Simms. As the house stands now it's over fifteen thousand dollars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it just doesn't seem possible -- (afterthought) for a house with such small rooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patiently) Mrs. Blandings, I've already explained. It's not only the size of the rooms so much as it is the number. You see, our primary problem is one of cubage -- JIM That's right, dear, cubage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- (sorry he got into it) just a figure of speech.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what does it mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little irritably) Cubage. It's just the number of cubic feet that -- (lost, lamely)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: go into a cubic foot. Go on, Simms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (consulting plans) Now is it absolutely essential for each of your daughters to have her own room with two closets and a separate bath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a look at the girls; clearing his throat) Yes. You see, er, my daughters are, er, approaching womanhood, and, er -- SIMMS (brief look at the girls) I hadn't realized they were approaching it quite so fast. (to Jim) Perhaps what you need is not so much a house as a series of little bungalows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmmm. (examining plans) What about that silly flower sink? We could eliminate that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I beg your pardon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or that sewing room upstairs, that's certainly a waste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we're going to eliminate anything, we'll lose that ridiculous play room in the basement with that great big poker table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, I've got to have some relaxation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got thirty-one and a half acres. Go out in the back and do a little gardening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, and get poison ivy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with dogged patience) If I may interrupt, I'd like to suggest that none of these are really major eliminations. Now if we could do with one less bathroom on the second floor -- MURIEL I'm sorry. We couldn't possibly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Blandings, a simple bathroom, eight by ten by eight with grade A fixtures will cost around thirteen hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I refuse to endanger the health of my children in a house with less than four bathrooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For thirteen hundred dollars they can live in a house with three bathrooms and rough it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, perhaps the most practical thing would be -- BETSY Oh, look, we're in the Lansdale paper! (reading) "Historical Society Blasts Vandalism!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muriel, Simms explained to you. We've just got to cut, cut -- (reacts) What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "Censure Vote Passed re Destruction of Famed Hackett Edifice."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, isn't that just too bad! Let me see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Prutty. Mrs. Bildad Prutty. Get a load of this! (reads) "The semi-monthly meeting of the Lansdale Historical Society was turned into an uproar last night when its president, Mrs. Bildad Prutty" -- How do you like that, Bildad Prutty? -- "reported the total demolition by its New York buyer of the historic old Hackett house." (laughs) Bildad Prutty! Muriel, I've got to send this to the New Yorker!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Read on, father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scans paper) "Mrs. Prutty," -- Bildad, that is -- "reminded her audience that several years ago the Society started to raise a fund to purchase and restore the old house to its original condition." (looks up, laughs scornfully)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Read on, father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (back to paper) "The project fell through by being seven hundred dollars short of the sum of twenty-six hundred dollars..." (Jim slows down as the following registers)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...which Ephemus Hackett testified was the lowest reasonable price he could accept as --"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) ...Twenty-six hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what did we pay, father?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eleven-five, with the commission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muriel, isn't it time for those children to be in bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now girls, I don't want to tell you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-six hundred dollars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (comfortingly) I wouldn't be too concerned about Mrs. Prutty and her committee. After all, it's your property and if you want to tear it down --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Why, Bill!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (briefly) Hello, Muriel. (he strides past her waving a telegram; to Jim) Well, you've done it again'. Once, just once, why don't you come to me and find out if it's all right, if it's legal, before you go barging off and run yourself smack into another jam!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's eating you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him; to Simms) And I must say, Simms, I hold you equally responsible!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) What? What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Simms; indicating Jim) Did you let this idiot tear down that house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if he did? What of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bill) Reconstruction was unsound and totally impractical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I quite agree. But you're dealing with a man who doesn't think before he acts, who goes off half-cocked!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it? What did I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him; to Simms) You're an architect! You must have been aware of the legality involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? What legality?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Simms) You knew there was a mortgage on that house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I assumed as much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened? What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him; to Simms) And you know the requirements in regard to a mortgage where there's demolition intended!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly. But since you were his lawyer, I naturally assumed -- BILL With a man like this you can't assume anything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (loudly) Just one minute! I am entitled to know what I did! This is America! A man's guilty until he's proven innocent -- BETSY It's the other way around, father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You go to bed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Girls!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bill, I've had a very trying day. Would you mind telling me in clear, concise English just what crime I've committed -- and why?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with weary resignation) In clear, concise English, you tore down a house on which another man holds a mortgage without first getting his written permission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I -- I did?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And in such case, the mortgagee can demand the full payment of said mortgage upon demand -- (waves telegram) and Mr. Ephemus Hackett so demands! Six thousand clams! And he wants them now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appalled) Now?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got ten days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For six thousand dollars we could have had a Solaxion house and a Crane Mobile home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muriel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (herding the kids toward the door) Girls, say your good nights and off to bed without another word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) Good night, Mr. Simms. Uncle Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (protesting) Miss Stellwagon says the problems of the parents should be the problems of the children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shooing them out) You keep that in mind, dear. It'll help prepare you for motherhood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps we'd better let the plans go for the time being and -- JIM (weakly) No, Simms, I'll work this out. You go ahead with your final plans and let's see some estimates.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And we'll just forget about that extra bathroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (preparing to leave) Very well. You'll hear from me as soon as possible. Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defeated) Six thousand dollars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'll you do for collateral on your building loan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, turn in my insurance policies or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming into scene) Now, Jim, you can't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if something should happen? You can't leave the children unprotected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (somewhat irritably) I'm not dead yet! And if I die, there's plenty left to take care of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not if you cash in your policies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure it won't be necessary. I'll see the boys at the bank. Maybe you can put up your insurance as collateral. If necessary, I'll sign a personal note.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wearily) Thanks, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (paternally) And Jim, do me a little favor. The next time you're going to do anything, or say anything, or buy anything, think it over very carefully, and when you're sure you're right -- forget the whole thing. Good night, Muriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a wonderful friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (darkly) What's with this kissing all of a sudden?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just because a man is helpful in a business way, it doesn't give him extra-curricular privileges with my wife!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a fine thing to say about a friend of fifteen years!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (testy) Well, I don't like it. Every time he goes out of this house, he shakes my hand and he kisses you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) Would you prefer it the other way around?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritably) Well, I don't like it, that's all! Why is he always hanging around? Why doesn't he ever get married -- or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (assumed innocence) Because he can't find another girl as sweet and pretty and wholesome as I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- it -- it doesn't look right. There are limits to friendship and --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darling, let's not be silly about this. It's not Bill, it's the house you're upset about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sigh) I suppose so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think it's worth all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, darling. We're not just building a house -- it's a home. A home for ourselves -- and our children -- and maybe our children's children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whimsically) It's getting awfully crowded with only three bathrooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- here are the estimates. Before you look at them, I think I'd better explain -- JIM Don't bother, Simms. (takes the sheet) I'm getting to be an old hand at this sort of --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jumping H. Mahogany --!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now obviously these bids are way out of line, that is, all except John Retch and Son at twenty-one thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reacting) Twenty-one thousand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And with some judicious cutting, I think we can pare that down to eighteen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've only asked for the barest necessities -- SIMMS Frankly, with all the extras you two have -- JIM Never mind. (hands estimates to Simms) If you'll just send us a bill for your services, I'll see that it's taken care of. (takes Muriel's hand and starts for door) Now, if you'll excuse us.

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am going out to get my head examined! Then, if I don't jump off the Brooklyn Bridge, I'm going to find the owner of our building and sign a twenty-year lease!

direction.raw_text: Over scene is the thunderous dissonance of the various SOUNDS that go into preliminary construction. A steam shovel in action, a bulldozer, the sawing of wood, and intermittently the loud, earth-shaking crash of a well-digger's rig. As the CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see the machines and workmen at their various tasks. The scene has all the rustic peace of the invasion of Hollandia. The ANGLE CHANGES, and we see Jim, Muriel, and Bill drive up the improvised driveway very close to the scene of activity.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another crash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts off. Muriel and Bill, curious, follow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Better take a look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic; to Jim) Thank you, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Mr. Zucca? Something wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you lika that? Broka my bucket. Two times this week I broka my bucket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do, strike a boulder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (darkly) Atsa no boulder, atsa ledge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) What does that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meansa we gotta blast!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blast. Witha dynamite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, dynamite?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little annoyed) What do you mean, "What do you mean?" Mr. Zucca just explained. He's going to use dynamite and blast until he gets rid of the rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Atsa no rock, atsa ledge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What Mr. Blandings means is -- what precisely is a ledge?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ledge. Lika bigga stone, only a- bigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like a boulder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, like ledge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Like a ledge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you don't gotta worry. Only cost twenty-four cents a cubic foot, plussa dynamite an'a fuse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how far will you have to blast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harda tell. Might be a lilla baby ledge -- mighta run the whole toppa the mountain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appalled) At twenty-four cents a foot? Do you realize what that means?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) Meansa we gotta blast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with quiet resignation) Well, anyway, our house will never sink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) If it does, we can always get Mr. Apollonio. He raised the Normandie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Come to peaceful Connecticut -- (another crash) Trade city soot for sylvan charm."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritably) How long does that go on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. (to Bill) Three weeks now at four dollars and fifty cents a foot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (asserting his authority) I think I'd better have a little talk with Mr. Tesander.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tesander, a stolid New England well-digger, the soul of industry and candor, attacks the earth. Jim, followed by Muriel and Bill, walks into scene, stands by, watching him. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The motor is making too much noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander looks up, shuts off his motor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a nod he turns on his motor, resumes work. Jim exchanges a look with Muriel and Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's drowned out by the motor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander patiently stops his motor, looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander looks at his equipment, considers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's about to turn on his motor, but Jim detains him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks at Bill who shakes his head with mock commiseration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks at Muriel for comfort which isn't forthcoming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander shakes his head, "No."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander shakes his head, "No."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns a little helplessly to Muriel and Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns on his motor, goes back to work. Jim, Muriel and Bill start to move off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a loud dynamite blast o.s. As a shower of dirt and rocks cascade down and they run for cover:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: JIM'S COST CHART - Jim stands casually above the house holding the line with one hand. The group pushing from below now consists of Smith, Hackett, Simms, Retch, Tesander, Zucca and assorted sub-contractors and workmen. As the house moves up a thousand dollars, Jim firmly pushes it back. It now rests at $33,500. DISSOLVE INT. JIM'S OFFICE - DAY Jim and Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a knock on the door. It opens and Bill Cole appears, briefcase under his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone rings. Mary answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends his hand. Jim absently shakes it, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he and Bill start for the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE EXCAVATION AT BALD MOUNTAIN - DAY Muriel, Jim, Bill, Simms and Retch stand at the edge looking down at the excavation which is partially filled with bubbling water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander walks into scene, looks down at the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander considers a moment, rubs his chin, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim exchanges a weary look with Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MONTAGE SPECIAL EFFECT: It consists of a Montage of the following DISSOLVING SHOTS: (1) The water being pumped out of the excavation. (2) The cement mixer pouring cement into wheelbarrows. (3) The pouring of the cement floor, walls and foundations. (4) Planks, shingles and plumbing equipment begin to arrive and are strewn about the property. (5) The exterior framing of the house begins to go up. (6) The sheathing is put on. (7) The roof is constructed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- Mr. Tesander --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (louder) Mr. Tesander!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's it coming?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (considers a moment; then:) It's comin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- no -- I mean --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouts) Mr. Tesander!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I meant was -- how far down are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- 'bout a hundred and ninety feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- isn't that pretty deep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks it over; he's not one for snap judgments; then:) Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think maybe you'd better try another spot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Up to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean -- well, have you hit anything yet at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks it over) Hit some limestone yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And right now it looks like we're coming into some shale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Course it might turn out to be sandstone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't tell. Might be good. Might be bad. One thing you know -- you got plenty of shale, sandstone and limestone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On a hot day there's nothing like a nice cool limestone shower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sweetly) Mr. Tesander, just for the record, of course, what ever happened to water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it's there, all right. (he smiles, nods, tips his hat to Muriel) Just got to be patient.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you ask me, this project's getting a little out of hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively) Nothing's getting out of hand at all. I've made a chart of the whole operation, and -- (indicates Tesander) with a few minor deviations, I know exactly what every penny's going to cost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two pennies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coolly) And just what does that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Meansa we gotta blast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, Mary, the average fellow who builds a house doesn't know where he stands from day to day -- but I do things a little differently. With a few minor deviations I know exactly where every penny is going --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bill! Come in, come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (entering) Just going over the Knapp contracts with old man Dascomb and I -- uh -- (indicates Mary) Can I talk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little concerned) Sure. What's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (obliquely) While I was in there with Dascomb the conversation kind of got around to you and -- uh -- JIM (impatiently) What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he didn't say in so many words that ever since you started with that house you haven't turned in a decent piece of copy, but -- JIM But you kind of got the feeling...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...that if I told you, you'd know that he knew that you knew that he knew... that you knew... or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he worrying about? The deadline's three months off. I've always --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello? Yes. Just a minute. (hands phone to Jim) Mrs. Blandings calling from Lensdale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Muriel. What? What's that? Tesander struck water! Say that's wonderful! (to Bill) We've finally got our well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (listens at phone) Huh? What's that? (face falls) What do you mean we've got two wells? (listens; then, grimly) I'll be right out. (hangs up, rises) Come on, Bill, we'd better get out to Lansdale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly, as he slips into his coat) Mary, have you ever seriously considered building a house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, no offense, Mr. Blandings, but my boy friend says that anybody who builds a house today is crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stick with that boy, he's got a great future.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you hit a spring, a bubbling spring right here in our cellar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll have to be diverted before Retch here can lay his cement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dubiously) May take a while. Pumps are over in Jersey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tsk, tsk, tsk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mild sarcasm) Water, Mr. Tesander.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At six feet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicates) And over there, just thirty-two yards away, you had to go down two hundred and twenty-seven feet to hit the same water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you account for that, Mr. Tesander?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We-ll, way it seems to me, Mr. Blandings, over here the water's down around six feet and over there it's -- uh -- BILL AND TESANDER -- down around two hundred and twenty- seven feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: IS SUPERIMPOSED: Jim's Cost Chart. - With each successive operation, a new workman is added to the already considerable group of people who are pushing the house inexorably upward, this against the frantic efforts of a slowly weakening Jim Blandings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BLANDINGS' HOUSE - DAY The exterior sheathing is completed and, in the roughest of terms, the project begins to resemble a house. Among the workmen's cars we notice the Blandings' convertible. DISSOLVE INT. THE INCOMPLETE LIVING ROOM - LOCATION #1 - DAY A dozen hammers, saws, trowels, etc. are heard in other parts of the house busily rasping and banging away. Jim and Muriel and Bill appear in the doorway before entering the rough unfinished interior of what will eventually be the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two workmen pass by carrying a few long pieces of lumber. The workmen don't see the Blandings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The workmen pass from view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they enter the foyer, a carpenter appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bill starts up the stairs, Jim and Muriel follow the carpenter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim throws a brief look at Muriel who is regarding him skeptically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After the sheerest pause there comes a shriek of nails brutally withdrawn from timber, a loud splintering of wood and then something of the appearance of entrails comes hurtling down end over end landing with a dusty slap at Jim's feet. The carpenter exits. Muriel gives Jim an accusing look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is another loud screech and more "entrails" come hurtling down, narrowly missing them. Muriel yells in the direction from which they came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From upstairs comes a long, shrill whistle. Instantly all sound of activity ceases and a voice is heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Muriel turns with apprehension, eighteen workmen come trooping down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the workmen exit the Blandings look at each other a little sheepishly, start up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's this, another closet?

dialogue.raw_text: This happens to be our dining room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not the dining room, dear, the living room. (indicates) There's the fireplace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then where's the dining room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it's that little room off the hallway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the breakfast nook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not the breakfast nook, it's the powder room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do me a favor -- don't ever invite me here for a meal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't figure this Blandings at all. If you gotta build on the windiest hill in Connecticut, why do you have to pick the windiest side of the hill?

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'd like to go outside.

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Un -- umm. No, I guess not.

dialogue.raw_text: (to Muriel) Now look what you've done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conciliatory) Look, men, Mrs. Blandings didn't mean anything. (the workmen regard him curiously) I mean, there's no point in walking off a job just because... a woman makes a silly little remark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Saturday, mister. We quit at twelve o'clock. This ain't a chain gang, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - as the Blandings go up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they reach the second floor landing, we hear, o.s. a steady but muffled pounding. They stop as they hear the thumping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They rush to the closet, open the heavy oak door. Bill is inside, leaning disgustedly against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bill starts to step out, Jim detains him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps inside with Bill, firmly closes the door. A moment's pause. The door re-opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ushers Muriel inside and the door closes on the threesome. The CAMERA REMAINS on the closed door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The knob turns, jiggles a little, but the door remains closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An efficient clockwise turn of the knob. Pause. An impatient doubletwist of the knob. Pause. A more forceful rattling of the knob, plus a slight kick. A furious rattling, pounding and kicking. The door remains closed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just sick. From the outside this house looks like a grain elevator, and on the inside everything's miles too small.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The door blew shut. I got locked in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Impossible. I had this closet built especially for myself. The lock opens from the inside.

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe for Houdini -- not for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing to it. A child could work it. Look, I'll show you.

dialogue.raw_text: (condescendingly) You see, it just takes a little good old Yankee know-how.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, dear, it's just possible the lock worked for you and not for Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ridiculous. Even you could do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, I'll show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, dear, just open it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't seem to be able to --- JIM'S VOICE Here, let me show you! You just take the knob and turn it clockwise.

direction.raw_text: . THE CLOSET As Jim turns sheepishly:

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Muriel is at the shoulder-high circular frame solid glass window. She looks out.

direction.raw_text: Jim and Bill look out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing like that good old Yankee know-how.

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Hey! Somebody let us out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, dear.

direction.raw_text: - THE LAST OF THE WORKMEN'S CARS WHAT THEY SEE - The last of the workmen's cars driving away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSET
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim gives him a look, turns back to the window, sizing up an escape, starts muttering to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tests the window frame, finds it solid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim picks up a piece of tar paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bill somewhat skeptically complies, Jim picks up a piece of two-by-four.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim raises the plank, takes a stance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim swings; the window shatters. Almost simultaneously there is a click and the door to the closet swings open. As Jim turns with a sense of accomplishment, his face falls as he and the others see that the erratic door has opened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Muriel and Bill precede Jim out of the closet and down the stairs, Jim pauses, speculatively toying with the lock.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (drily) Leave a call for seven o'clock. (afterthought) Monday morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I could just get over to that scaffolding...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still muttering) Seems a shame but I guess it's the only way...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get panicky, I'll get you out of here. (hands tar paper to Bill) Here, hold this over the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand back, Muriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bill) Ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Roger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sweetly) In case of emergency -- break glass. Come on, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) Funny... always worked before. Huh. I wonder...

direction.raw_text: Muriel and Bill walking down the stairs. From upstairs comes a steady sullen pounding from the interior of the closet. Without a word, they stop, look at each other, turn and walk back upstairs.

direction.raw_text: . THE BLANDINGS' BREAKFAST NOOK - DAY Muriel and the children are having breakfast. Jim enters, in fairly high spirits, once again improvising to "Home On The Range."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim suddenly explodes, crumpling a letter he has just read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignoring her, he reaches for the phone, starts to dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Muriel's reaction:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROAD AND COVERED BRIDGE - DAY Two moving vans are approaching the bridge. Behind them is the Blandings' convertible. In it are Jim, Muriel and the children. Behind it and attached is a trailer. After a pause, over this, we hear:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as he sits down) "Home, home in Connecticut -- Where you have to conform to local traditions, customs, politics and etiquette..." (picks up his morning mail, starts to thumb through it)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, do you suppose I could have a chemistry lab in the basement?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (preoccupied with mail) Sure, why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's awful. Smelling up the house with those horrible chemicals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind, Betsy. (to Jim) Dear, I'm going up to the place this afternoon to see about landscaping. Bill's driving me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (preoccupied) That's nice. (looking up; darkly) What do you mean, Bill's driving you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little annoyed) Why do you always say, "what do you mean," when you know perfectly well what I mean and what you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean that every time I turn my back Bill Cole's driving you some place or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's only being helpful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed; tears open a letter) I thought he was a lawyer! Why isn't he out suing somebody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bicker, bicker, bicker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Joan) Another word and you don't get your laboratory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's something!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll just see about that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (concerned) What is it, dear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim, what's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone; sharply) Mr. William Cole, please. (pause; then with rising emotion) Hello, Bill? I want you to fight this thing! I know my rights as a citizen! They can't get away with it!... What do you mean, what am I talking about? The letter, of course. From the owner of this building. They want us to move! It's a thirty day notice! (listens a moment) But that's ridiculous. How can I move into a house that isn't even finished?! No windows, no plaster -- or paint, or -- or plumbing! (listens a moment; then with rising emotion) Now you listen to me! I have no intention of moving in thirty days! This is not legal! I'm going to fight this thing! And I don't care if it takes every penny I've got! (listens) Yeah... Yeah... Yeah... All right! (hangs up)
