dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm beginning to wonder! (exploding) Maybe it was those big cow eyes of yours or that ridiculous hole in your chin! Maybe I knew that some day you'd bring me out to this thirty- eight thousand dollar icebox with a dried-up trout stream and no windows! Or maybe I just happened to fall in love with you -- but for heaven's sake, don't ask me why!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim enters. Muriel stands with her back to him angrily winding the clock. Jim noisily clears his throat. No reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim gently turns her around facing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel looks at Jim. Finally she smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes into his arms and they kiss intimately. As their lips part:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim again kisses her tenderly, warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim kisses her again, a little more ardently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Each gets into his own bed, still wearing the overcoats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: JIM'S COST CHART - The house now wavers at $37,000. As Jim and Muriel still try to stem the tide, the group that is pushing the house ever upward includes all of the previous people connected with the house and -- in addition --plumbers, painters, landscape gardeners, etc. Over this, and across the scene flutter more bills, more extras.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RADIO CITY - NIGHT (STOCK) It is raining. The lights are on in the buildings.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (tentatively) ...Muriel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Honey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would it do any good to say I'm sorry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- I am. I acted like a schoolboy and I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Jim!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dreamily) Why don't you take the soap out of your ears?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (same) Why do I love you so much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breathless) Darling, it's awfully late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (same) Maybe you ought to go down and lock the doors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kissing her ear) What for? The windows are all open anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he starts to kiss her again) Jim, you have to get up at six o'clock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (considers; logic prevails; brief sigh) Yes, I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) Goodnight, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (same) Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And so the days sped by -- and the bills -- and the extras -- and as the house approached forty thousand dollars, Jim approached his deadline for the new slogan. It was almost a photo finish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary is attending to some detail work as the door opens and Jim enters, disturbed. Mary looks at him questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up a pencil, nibbles on it thoughtfully. The silence in the room is broken only by the patter of raindrops on the window. It strikes a note in Jim's subconscious. He swivels around in his chair and stares soberly out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks at him curiously. He turns to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he starts to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BLANDINGS' LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Note: The house is painted and almost completely furnished. A hard rain beats on the windows. There is a blazing fire in the fireplace. Muriel, in a warm bathrobe, sits near it, comfortably knitting. In fact, the scene is exactly the one Jim has just described, except that the man with slippers, pipe and smoking jacket, reading the paper, is Bill Cole. Near the fire, Bill's rain-drenched jacket, shirt and shoes are hanging up to dry. The cozy tranquillity is broken by a sharp RINGING of the front doorbell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA FOLLOWS Bill to the front door. He opens it. A man in raincoat and boots stands there in the pouring, driving rain. The man enters as Bill struggles to get the door shut against the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees Jones' doubtful look at the smoking jacket, feels an explanation is necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel walks into scene. Jones takes in the bathrobe, again looks skeptically at Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door is opened with a terrific swirl of wind and rain. Jones exits as Muriel and Bill push the door against the wind, finally getting it shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they start back into the living room:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muriel pokes the dying fire, looks up thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JIM'S OFFICE - EARLY MORNING The CAMERA COMES IN ON a package of cigarettes. A finger impatiently rips open what is left of the package, discloses that it is empty. The ANGLE WIDENS to reveal a tired, disheveled Jim. Disgusted, he fishes the most likely butt from a tray littered with them. With considerable difficulty he manages to light it, only to burn his nose. Impatiently stamping out the butt he rises, stretches, walks to the window, pulls up the shade. Early morning sunlight floods the room. He turns off a standing lamp, looks thoughtfully out the window, suddenly gets an idea. Turning, he snaps his fingers. Mary, who is asleep on the desk, her head resting on her elbows, raises her head, opens a sleepy eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary critically shakes her head "no", closes her eye. Jim wearily throws himself down on the couch, absently toys with his already loosened tie. He pulls it up over his nose, throwing the balance over the top of his head. Suddenly he reacts, snaps his fingers. Mary opens a sleepy eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eye closes. Jim sinks back with defeat, his hand dropping over the edge of the couch. It encounters a crumpled piece of paper, earlier work. He smoothes the paper, scans it, kind of likes it. He gets up, comes over, snaps fingers. Mary looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long silent look passes between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He suddenly and angrily gathers all his papers, slams them into the wastebasket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks at him sympathetically, doesn't quite know what to say. As the CAMERA MOVES to a CLOSE SHOT of the emotionally distraught Jim, his eyes go to a large photograph on his desk of Muriel and the children. He picks it up, looks at it with affection. Suddenly he gets an idea. Rising with determination he puts on his coat and starts for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE BLANDINGS' HOME - DAY It is an especially beautiful, sunshiny morning. A rural- looking taxi deposits a weary Jim, who pays the driver. As the cab drives off, Jim looks speculatively at Simms' car, which is parked there, yawns, stretches, opens the door and enters. Under this a slightly sour underscoring of "Home On The Range."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd better send out for coffee and sandwiches,... It looks like an all night session.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (concerned) What did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wearily, seating himself at desk) Tomorrow morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Well, I guess you'll just have to dream something up -- good or bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I rather got the impression it had better be good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raised eyebrow) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ruminatively, almost to himself) Funny how you look forward to the little things. Rain, for instance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For a month now, I guess I've been looking forward to the first rainy night at the house. (looks at Muriel's picture) Big blazing fire. Muriel knitting. Me in my new smoking jacket... with my pipe and slippers, reading my paper... (sighs) Oh, well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with relief) Thank heavens! The children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) Stay put. You look too comfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . JONES Whew! What a night! I'm Jones, from down the road. Just came over to tell you your kids are all right, Mr. Blandings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm not Mr. Blandings. Cole's the name, Bill Cole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friend of the family. Wet clothes. Just came in out of the rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Mrs. Blandings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do. Mrs. Williams just called. Says your phone's out of order. Wanted me to tell you the water's rising and they've got the bridge roped off. Girls'll spend the night over at her place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I was beginning to get concerned. Can I make you a cup of tea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thanks. Better be gettin' back 'fore I have to swim for it. 'Night, Mrs. Blandings. (to Bill) 'Night, Mr. Bl--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weak smile) Cole. Bill Cole. Friend of the family. Just came in out of the rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncertainly) Well -- 'Night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight... and thanks so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine. No bridge. How do I get back to Lansdale?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) You'll just have to spend the night right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Muriel, really! With your husband in New York and your children away -- think of my reputation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smile) Don't worry, Snow White, you'll be as pure and unsullied in the morning as you were the night before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with resignation) That's the story of my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor Jim, he sounded so worried before. I certainly hope he comes up with something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about the man who gave the world "When you've got the whim, say Wham!"-- This well will never run dry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (selling; a note of desperation in his voice) "Compare the price, compare the slice, Take our advice -- Buy Wham!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "If you'd buy better ham. You'd better buy Wham!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Boyle Petroleum. "If you'd buy better oil, You'd better buy Boyle."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "This little pig went to market As meek and as mild as a lamb. He smiled in his tracks When they slipped him the axe He knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising panic) It's gone! I've lost my touch! Maybe I never had a touch! Maybe "Whim Say Wham" was an accident! Who knows? I can't think any more! All I've got on my mind is a house with an eighteen thousand dollar mortgage, and bills, and extras, and antiques, and -- and -- (dejected) I don't know... I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home, to get some sleep -- and I'd advise you to do the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- but you haven't -- JIM Suppose I haven't! This isn't the only job in town!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- but -- what'll I tell Mr. Dascomb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) You just tell him to -- to -- (with finality) You just tell him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Jim comes into the foyer, he sees Muriel, in nightgown and robe, talking to Mr. Simms. She holds the rolled-up volume of blueprints that went into building the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he unrolls the blueprints, Jim looks suspiciously at Muriel. She seems a little nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the above speech Simms sinks into a chair, puts his head in his hands and closes his eyes, a fact that isn't lost on Jim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim takes a deep breath, turns to Simms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Morning, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going to him; solicitously) Darling, you must be exhausted. How did it go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (obliquely) Is... everything all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unenthusiastic) Everything's fine. (still in embrace; looking up) Hello, Simms, what brings you out with the morning dew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just dropped by to check the blueprints. Some extras came in from Retch this morning and there're a couple of things I thought we ought to go over together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (arms still around Muriel; unconcerned) Really. What are they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's see. (thumbing through sheets) Few little things here, all right, I guess. "Mortising five butts -- a dollar sixty-eight."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not quibble about that. A man's entitled to mortise a few butts now and then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (next sheet) Extra nails and screws -- three dollars, eighty-nine cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Petty larceny, but let him get away with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now there's one here I frankly don't understand. Ah, here we are. (reads) "Changes in closet, twelve hundred and forty-seven dollars." Did you authorize that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we probably told him to -- (reacting) Twelve hundred and what?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty-seven dollars. Changes in closet. (hands bill to Jim)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explosively) Who does he think we are! (looks at bill; very businesslike) What's this notation: "Refer to Detail Sheet Number one thirty-five?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating blueprints) Far as I remember, that would be something in the back of the house. Let's just take a look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, here we are. It isn't a closet at all. It's off the back pantry... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Muriel) You didn't authorize any changes, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively) Well... they certainly weren't changes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What -- have -- you -- done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking rapidly a little confused) I haven't done anything! And what I did was... just nothing at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What -- have -- you -- done?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- (rattling off) All I did was one day I saw four pieces of flagstone left over from the porch that were just going to be thrown away because nobody wanted them and I asked Mr. Retch if he wouldn't just put them down on the floor of the flower sink and poke a little cement between the cracks and give me a nice stone floor where it might be wet with flowers and things. That was absolutely all I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all you did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely. Just four little pieces of flagstone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Muriel; wearily) Did you by any chance authorize a drain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (verge of tears) Of course I didn't. All I said was I wanted a nice stone floor and Mr. Retch was just as nice as could be and said, "You're the doctor," and that's all anybody ever said to anybody about anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sigh; plunging in) All right, I think I can tell you what happened. First, the carpenters had to rip up the flooring that was already laid. Those planks run under the whole width of the pantry, so Retch had to knock the bottom out of the pantry wall to get at them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jim and Muriel - Jim looks at Muriel as though he were premeditating first-degree murder. She averts his gaze. Over this:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Then he had to chop out the tops of the joists under the flower sink space to make room for a cradle. I guess he bought some iron straps and fastened them to a big pan to give him something to hold the cement. What with that added load on the weakened joists, I'll bet he had to put a lally column down there for support, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was just four little pieces of flagstone, and I only --- JIM Quiet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - During the following speech we see Bill Cole, in Jim's pajamas and robe come down the stairs and enter the room. Jim and Muriel are not aware of his presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim turns away, reacts, suddenly turns back to Bill, taking in the pajamas and robe. A little shocked but unwilling to believe the implication of what he sees, he looks to Muriel for an explanation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks at Bill, then back at Muriel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the main soil pipe runs under there on wall brackets, so Retch had to get his plumbing man back to take out a section so he could get that cradle set. I guess that meant he had to change the pitch of the soil pipe from one end of the house to the other. (looks up) 'Morning, Mr. Cole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Morning. Hello, Jim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) Hello, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lamely) The bridge was roped off and Bill had to stay last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cheerily) Slept like a rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm delighted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clearing his throat) And then, of course, there are hot and cold water pipes hooked to the joists right under that pantry. They go up to the wing bathroom on the second floor, and I'll bet my bottom dollar he had to relocate them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Jim, Muriel and Bill. Jim turns to listen but finds himself looking speculatively at Muriel and Bill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And I guess the electrician had to rip out about sixty feet of armored cable between the main panel and the junction box by the oil burner, including the two hundred twenty volt cable that goes to the stove.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Gussie appears in the doorway in raincoat, carrying umbrella.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Jim reacts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Gussie exits, Muriel turns to Simms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Embarrassed pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill exits. Another pause. Simms, aware of the tension, wants to get out of there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through Simms' speech, Jim looks darkly at Muriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves. There is a deadly pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the b.g. Mr. Tesander enters, cap in hand, stands there, nervous and embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tesander clears his throat. Jim turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A slight embarrassed pause. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a momentary pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands the money to Jim, who stares at it blankly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks haplessly at Muriel, sheepish, guilty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim and Muriel look at each other a little sheepishly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Morning, everybody. Whew! What a night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where have you been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lansdale. Couldn't get back across the bridge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You... weren't here last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They weren't letting anybody across that bridge, Mr. Blandings. (to Muriel) I passed the girls over at the Williams. They'll be along any minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Thank you, Gussie. You'd better get breakfast started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where were we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were at the two hundred twenty volt cable that goes to the stove.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a minute. (looks at Bill, then at Muriel) You mean the children weren't here last night either?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could they be, dear? The bridge was closed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just came across it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it was closed last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointedly) It's open now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (attempt at breeziness) If you'll all excuse me -- I -- I think I'll just go up and slip into something a little more comfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rapidly) Well, that's about the size of it --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: except that Retch had to repair the pantry wall and that meant getting a plasterer back. And of course, he couldn't have broken through that wall -- JIM All right, Simms, all right. We'll take care of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (preparing to exit) I'll admit it's a little steep. But I'll try to get Retch to knock a hundred dollars off the bill. If I can't get that, I'll certainly try for seventy-five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he doesn't go for seventy-five, I'll take a stab at fifty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at the door) Anyway, I'm almost sure we can get twenty-five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lamely) Well. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (carefully) Now dear, you're upset, you've got a lot of things on your mind -- JIM (with dangerous calm) Muriel, there's only one thing on my mind -- This house -- and how fast we can get rid of it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what you're thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it's not. Maybe I'm thinking I was once a happy man! (the martyr) I didn't have a closet, I didn't have three bathrooms, but I did have my sanity, a few dollars in the bank, two children who loved me and a wife I could trust!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a fine thing to say!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I also had a job at Danton and Bascomb, something I don't happen to have at the moment!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, I've resigned! We're starting all over again! From scratch! And without this house!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (near tears) You love this house!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hate it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't mean that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every word of it! Anybody who builds a house today is crazy! The minute you start, they put you on the list. The All-American Sucker list! Everywhere you turn they've got a hand in your pocket. If you take out their hands, they find more pockets! (explosively) It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a conspiracy against every man and woman who want a home of their own! Against every boy and girl who were ever in love!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) What do you want?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shyly) Well, Mr. Blandings, there's a matter of twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a wild gleam) Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents! Why be a piker, Mr. Tesander? (emptying pockets) Take everything I've got! Spread it out among your pals! (advancing toward the bewildered Tesander) Wouldn't Retch like a little something? Maybe Zucca could use my new dinner jacket? It's open house, Mr. Tesander! Help yourself! If this isn't enough I'll come over to your place and do some odd chores. Maybe I can mow your lawn or scratch your back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) You don't understand, Mr. Blandings. This twelve dollars and eighty-six cents -- you don't owe me, I owe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...W-what was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking out money) Found I overcharged you. Almost three feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better count it. I think it's all there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much, Mr. Tesander.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I guess I'd better be gettin' along. (looking around) Sure got a pretty place here. (at door; pauses; looks back) I'll tell Mr. Zucca about the dinner jacket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Tesander is about to exit, Bill, dressed, starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Tesander -- could you give me a lift to town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be right with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (concerned) What did you mean before about losing your job? Will we really have to sell the house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim and Muriel look at him curiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bill turns and leaves, the outer door is heard opening and the kids appear. There is an exchange of "Hi's" as they pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gussie's head appears from the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gussie's head disappears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (miserable) I don't know, dear... I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In case anyone's interested, I'm leaving for town. (for Jim's benefit) If you want to count the silverware, I'll wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sheepishly) Bill, be patient with me. Maybe one of these days I'll grow up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Muriel) What happened to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind if I say something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I've kind of been the voice of doom about this whole project. Every step of the way I was firmly convinced you were getting fleeced, bilked, rooked, flimflammed and generally taken to the cleaners. And maybe you were. Maybe it cost you a whole lot more than you thought it would. Maybe there were times when you wished you'd never started the whole thing. But when I look around and see what you two have here -- I don't know. (pause) Maybe there are some things you should buy with your heart and not with your head. Maybe those are the things that really count... See you around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Morning, everybody!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Hi, Dad! How come you're not at the office?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a look at Muriel) I'm on a... kind of a vacation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you got fired?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, not exactly, I -- MURIEL We'll discuss it later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (brightly) Come and get it! Breakfast everybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! I'm starving! What are we having, Gussie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Orange juice, scrambled eggs and you- know-what.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (making a face) Ham?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not ham -- Wham! (cheerily) If you ain't eatin' Wham, you ain't eatin' ham!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Jim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reacts with the sudden exhilaration of Balboa first seeing the Pacific. He snaps his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes light up as he begins to visualize.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ADVERTISEMENT IN MAGAZINE - It is a picture of Gussie, smiling, holding a platter with an enormous ham. Under it, the simple caption:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did she say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darling, give Gussie a ten dollar raise!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WIDENS TO DISCLOSE MR. JAMES BLANDINGS THE CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to disclose Mr. James Blandings reclining in a hammock on the patio of his Dream House. In the b.g. Muriel is working at her garden, Joan and Betsy assisting her. Jim reacts with pride and satisfaction as he sets the magazine down, takes a long drink of lemonade and picks up a book which he has been reading. As the CAMERA COMES IN for an EXTREME CLOSE SHOT of Jim we see the title of the book on the jacket cover. It reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jim looks up over the top of the book, directly into the camera and winks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the CAMERA PULLS AWAY to a LONG SHOT tableau of the Blandings and their Dream House, we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BLANDINGS BUILDS HIS DREAM HOUSE"
